scaledic 0.1.7.10

  • Changelog

    Introduction to scaledic

    scaledic.rmd

    Note

    This is a short description on how to use the scaledic package. The following code examples in this package make use of the pipe operator %>% (see the magrittr package).
    Once you are used to the pipe operator, it makes code easier to read. Basically, it is just a shortcut. The pipe operator takes the return of the previous function and sets it as the first argument of the following function. An example:

    newdat <- select(dat, "iq", "age")
newdat <- describe(newdat)
newdat <- round(newdat, 2)
kable(newdat)

    or even worth

    kable(round(describe(select(dat, "iq", "age")), 2))

    becomes:

    dat %>%
  select("iq", "age") %>%
  describe() %>%
  round(2) %>%
  kable()

    How to use scaledic

    You need two things:

    1. a dataset,
    2. a dictionary file.

    A dictionary file

    A dictionary file is a table with a row for each variable and a column for each parameter of those variables. Most conviniently, you prepare a dictionary file in a spreadsheet program for later use with datasets.

    The following table shows the parameters and the naming of the columns of a dictionary file:

    Columns of a dictionary file
    Parameter Meaning Example
    label A short item label itrf_1
    scale Abreviation of the scale the item belongs to irtf
    subscale Abrevation of the sub scale int
    subscale_2 Abrevation of the second order sub scale shy
    scale_label Name of the scale Integrated Teacher Report Form
    subscale_label Name of the sub scale internalizing problems
    subscale_2_label Name of the second order sub scale shyness
    item Full text of the item Vermeidet die Teilnahme an Diskussionen im Unterricht
    index An index number 1
    values Valid response values in an R manner 1:5 (for integers 1 to 5) 1,2,3 (for integers 1, 2, 3)
    value_labels Labels for each response value 0 = nicht; 1 = leicht; 2 = mäßig; 3 = stark
    missing Missing values -888, -999
    type Data type (factor, integer, float, real) integer
    weight Reversion of item and its weight 1 (positive), -1 (reverse), 1.5 (positive, weights 1.5 times)
    source Reference Casale et al. (2017)
    note Further notes Item has low descrimination

    Here is extract of a dic file from the included example:

    dic_ITRF %>% slice(1:3) 
#>      label index scale sub_scale SUB_SCALE_2                    scale_label
#> 1 itrf_I_1     1  ITRF       Int          SW Integrated teacher report form
#> 2 itrf_I_2     2  ITRF       Int          AD Integrated teacher report form
#> 3 itrf_I_4     4  ITRF       Int          SW Integrated teacher report form
#>   sub_scale_label  sub_scale_2_label
#> 1   Internalizing Socially Withdrawn
#> 2   Internalizing  Anxious/Depressed
#> 3   Internalizing Socially Withdrawn
#>                                           item weight values
#> 1               Verbringt zu viel Zeit alleine      1    0:3
#> 2 Beschwert sich über Krankheit oder Schmerzen      1    0:3
#> 3              Vermeidet soziale Interaktionen      1    0:3
#>                                                                               value_labels
#> 1 0 = not problematic; 1 = slightly problematic; 2 = problematic; 3 = strongly problematic
#> 2 0 = not problematic; 1 = slightly problematic; 2 = problematic; 3 = strongly problematic
#> 3 0 = not problematic; 1 = slightly problematic; 2 = problematic; 3 = strongly problematic
#>   missing    type                            source note
#> 1     -99 integer Volpe et al. et al. (unpublished) <NA>
#> 2     -99 integer Volpe et al. et al. (unpublished) <NA>
#> 3     -99 integer Volpe et al. et al. (unpublished) <NA>

    Apply a dictionary file

    When you combine a dataset with a dictionary file, each variable in the dataset which corresponds to a variable described in the dictionary will be complemented with the given dictionary information.
    The resulting dataset now is ready to be used with all further scaledic functions.

    The apply_dic function takes the name of the dataset and the dictionary file and combines them. Thereby replacing missing values with NAs:

    # Here we use the example dataset "ITRF" and the example dic file "dic_ITRF"
dat <- apply_dic(ITRF, dic_ITRF)

    Let us get an overview of all scales in the dataset:

    list_scales(dat, labels = TRUE, n_items = TRUE)
#> # A tibble: 4 x 9
#>   Scale Subscale Subscale_2 `Label scale` `Label subscale` `Label subscale…
#>   <chr> <chr>    <chr>      <chr>         <chr>            <chr>           
#> 1 ITRF  Ext      APD        Integrated t… Externalizing    Academic Produc…
#> 2 ITRF  Ext      OPP        Integrated t… Externalizing    Oppositional/Di…
#> 3 ITRF  Int      AD         Integrated t… Internalizing    Anxious/Depress…
#> 4 ITRF  Int      SW         Integrated t… Internalizing    Socially Withdr…
#> # … with 3 more variables: `n Scale` <chr>, `n Subscale` <chr>, `n Subscale
#> #   2` <chr>

    Clean raw data

    Firstly, we check for invalid values in the dataset (e.g., typos) and replace these with NA:

    dat <- check_values(dat, replace = NA)

    Now we impute missing values:

    # Imputation for items of the subscale Ext
dat <- impute_missing(dat, subscale == "Ext")

# Imputation for items of the subscale Int
dat <- impute_missing(dat, subscale == "Int")

    Select scales for analyszing

    Let us see descriptive statistics for the Internalizing sub scale:

    dat %>% 
  select_scale(subscale == "Int") %>%
  psych::describe(fast = TRUE) %>%
  round(1)
#>           vars    n mean  sd min max range se
#> itrf_I_1     1 4772  0.4 0.7   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_2     2 4772  0.4 0.7   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_4     3 4772  0.3 0.6   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_5     4 4772  0.2 0.6   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_6     5 4772  0.2 0.5   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_7     6 4772  0.4 0.7   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_8     7 4772  0.3 0.7   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_9     8 4772  0.5 0.8   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_10    9 4772  0.3 0.7   0   3     3  0
#> itrf_I_11   10 4772  0.3 0.7   0   3     3  0

    See items instead of labels

    It is more convinient to see the original items instead of the short lables:

    dat %>% 
  select_scale(subscale == "Int") %>%
  names2item() %>%
  psych::describe(fast = TRUE) %>%
  round(1)

    And further we analyse the factor structure

    dat %>%
  select_scale(scale == "ITRF") %>%
  names2item(chars = 70, prefix = c("reverse", "subscale", "subscale2")) %>% 
  psych_fa(nfactors = 4, cut = 0.4)
#>                                                                         MR1

    and provide item analyses

    scales <- list(
  'Academic Productivity/ Disorganization' = get_index(dat, subscale_2 == "APD"),
  'Opposotional/ Disruptive' = get_index(dat, subscale_2 == "OPP"),
  "Socialy Withdrawn" = get_index(dat, subscale_2 == "SW"),
  "Anxious/ Depressed" = get_index(dat, subscale_2 == "AD")
)
alpha_table(dat, scales = scales)
#>                                    Scale    n n items  Alpha(CI95%)
#> 1 Academic Productivity/ Disorganization 4776       8  .91 (.9-.91)
#> 2               Opposotional/ Disruptive 4776       9 .94 (.93-.94)
#> 3                      Socialy Withdrawn 4772       8 .88 (.87-.88)
#> 4                     Anxious/ Depressed 4772      11 .88 (.88-.89)
#>   Std.Alpha(CI95%) Homogeneity Discrimination           M          SD |Loading|
#> 1    .91 (.91-.91)         .56      .53 - .78 0.38 - 0.95 0.75 - 1.04 .55 - .82
#> 2    .94 (.94-.94)         .63      .68 - .81 0.35 - 0.83 0.72 - 0.96  .7 - .85
#> 3    .88 (.88-.89)         .49      .53 - .78 0.21 - 0.43 0.51 - 0.76 .56 - .86
#> 4    .88 (.88-.89)         .41      .52 - .69 0.23 - 0.48 0.59 - 0.77 .55 - .74

    Build scale scores

    Now we build scores for internalizing and externalizing scales

    dat$itrf_ext <- score_scale(dat, scale == "ITRF" & subscale == "Ext")
dat$itrf_int <- score_scale(dat, scale == "ITRF" & subscale == "Int")

    and get descriptives for these scores

    dat %>%
  select_scores() %>%
  psych::describe(fast = TRUE) %>%
  round(1)
#>          vars    n mean  sd min max range se
#> itrf_ext    1 4776  0.6 0.6   0 3.0   3.0  0
#> itrf_int    2 4772  0.3 0.4   0 2.6   2.6  0
